qas.question: Why is cycling popular in Tucson?

answers.text: its flat terrain and dry climate
a network of seven linear parks

qas.question: How many miles of trails are in The Loop?
What organization advises the Tucson government on bike concerns?
What kind of places to ride bikes does Tucson have?

answers.text: marked bike routes, signal crossings, on-street bike lanes, mountain-biking trails, and dedicated shared-use paths

context: Cycling is popular in Tucson due to <a0_0>its flat terrain and dry climate<a0_0/>. Tucson and Pima County maintain an extensive network of <a4_0>marked bike routes, signal crossings, on-street bike lanes, mountain-biking trails, and dedicated shared-use paths<a4_0/>. The Loop is <a1_0>a network of seven linear parks<a1_0/> comprising <a2_0>over 100<a2_0/> mi (160 km) of paved, vehicle-free trails that encircles the majority of the city with links to Marana and Oro Valley. The <a3_0>Tucson-Pima County Bicycle Advisory Committee<a3_0/> (TPCBAC) serves in an advisory capacity to local governments on issues relating to bicycle recreation, transportation, and safety. Tucson was awarded a gold rating for bicycle-friendliness by the League of American Bicyclists in 2006.
